sen.j: 小石 元瑞（こいし げんずい、天明4年11月20日 (旧暦)（1784年12月31日） - 嘉永2年2月10日 (旧暦)（1849年3月4日））は、江戸時代後期の蘭学者、蘭方医。
sen.e: Genzui KOISHI (December 31, 1784 - March 4, 1849) was a Dutch scholar and Ranpoi (a person who studied Western medicine by means of the Dutch language) in the late Edo period.

Genzui KOISHI (December 31, 1784 - March 4, 1849) was a Rangakusha (a person who studied Western sciences by means of the Dutch language) and Ranpoi (a person who studied Western medicine by means of the Dutch language) who lived during the late Edo period.

Genzui KOISHI (December 31, 1784 - March 4, 1849) was a Rangakusha (a person who studied Western sciences by means of the Dutch language) and Ranpoi (a person who studied Western medicine by means of the Dutch language) who lived during the late Edo period.

sen.j: 新宮凉庭とともに京都の二大蘭方医と称揚される。
sen.e: He was praised as two great Ranpoi in Kyoto with Ryotei SHINGU.
Along with Ryotei SHINGU, he was praised as one of the two great Ranpoi in Kyoto.
Along with Ryotei SHINGU, he was praised as one of the two great Ranpoi in Kyoto.

sen.e: His father was a doctor, Genshun KOISHI.
His father, Genshun KOISHI, was a doctor.
His father, Genshun KOISHI, was a doctor.

sen.j: 名は龍または橘龍、字を矼軒。
sen.e: His name was Ryu or Kitsuryu and his azana (another name) was Koken.

sen.e: His second name or alias are 檉園・蘭斎・秋巖仙史・拙翁・用拙居・用拙居主人・松芝老人・五竹茶寮.

sen.j: 元瑞は病弱だったが父小石元俊に厳しく育てられた。
sen.e: Although Genzui was in poor health, he was brought up strictly by his father, Gensyun KOISHI, and he entered Santo SHINOZAKI's Baika Juku (Baika private school) in Osaka to study keigaku (study of Keisho in Confucianism) in his childhood.

sen.e: He went down to Edo at the age of 16, and he learned Western learning and medical science from teachers such as Genpaku SUGITA, Gentaku OTSUKI and Genzui UDAGAWA.

sen.e: After he returned to Kyoto, he became 漢蘭折衷医 and took over his father's private school Kyuri-do.

sen.j: 医業の傍ら漢詩・書・煎茶・茶の湯などに親しみ、青木木米・田能村竹田・浦上春琴・山本梅逸・小田海僊・頼山陽・篠崎小竹・細川林谷・市河米庵を始め、多くの文人と交友した。
sen.e: Besides practicing medicine, he enjoyed Chinese poetry, calligraphy, green tea, the art of the tea ceremony and so on, and had a friendship with many literary men including Mokubei AOKI, Chikuden TANOMURA, Shunkin URAGAMI, Baiitsu YAMAMOTO, Kaisen ODA, Sanyo RAI, Shochiku SHINOZAKI, Rinkoku HOSOKAWA and Beian ICHIKAWA.
